commentBody:
My farmer's jokes are corny, but my optometrist's are cornea.

(But they both have a good field of vision.)

Happy to see a rebus to spice up a Sunday puzzle. I‚Äôm frequently foiled by TV clues because I don‚Äôt have a head for names, so I was unfamiliar with _ yra Phillips and not 100% sure about Brendan Fraser. Pair that with not having Popeye‚Äôs dawn on me for the longest time, and that Erlen Meyer flask was a doozy to put together. 

A fine puzzle. Would have liked a little more chewiness (came in just under 20 min even though we‚Äôre all watching a game and I‚Äôm on my 3rd beer).

T 28.47
B 10.16
A 35.11

6009 solved
100 % solved rate
752 current streak
752 longest streak

No look up

Nice theme but too many proper nouns, brand names and Disney characters for my liking.  Bordering on a Natick city. 

ü•∫
This was fun! Got the rebus with Hawkeye. Always need to look up some names. Much faster than my average. Loved it. Thanks, y‚Äôall!
Wow, a LOT of proper names, most of which were obscure to me. I enjoyed the theme, tho.

Multiple early comments about the number of (or too many) names or other proper nouns. I certainly don't claim to know more proper nouns than anyone else, but I didn't notice this in my solve. Are you folks saying you couldn't use crosses to figure out the names (as I did), or are you just saying you didn't know them straight off from the clues (as I probably didn't either)?

I‚Äôm a little on the fence on how I feel about this one. On the one hand, it‚Äôs a very well constructed grid, I don‚Äôt have many nits except EHOW and HOWODD in the same puzzle, and not a fan of topsy turviness as a clue for HAVOC. I think it‚Äôs about average difficulty for a Sunday. A few clever clues, I especially liked SHINER and HOARD. And I‚Äôm certainly not averse to rebuses, quite the contrary, and this one was done very consistently with a cute revealer, and all the across having the EYE letters hidden and the downs with the EYE more obvious. BUT is anyone else just a little bored of puzzles with a single repeated rebus? I felt similarly with the recent TEN ANTS puzzle. Am I just too jaded? It‚Äôs just that you find the rebus, look for it over and over in the other themed clues which were ok but not overly interesting, and you are done and say, ok that‚Äôs it? Maybe I‚Äôm just going through a crossword ennui crisis (been solving these about 6 years). Someone slap me around if you think I‚Äôm just being catty.

I enjoyed this one ! Got the theme at 96A when i could see there were not enough spaces. 

And this was my first encounter with the name of that piece of lab equipment (39A) since my general science class back in the ‚Äò60s where we had to draw pictures of and label all the items we used in our lab exercises. I was amused to read just now in Wikipedia that until 2019 you had to have a permit to buy one in Texas.
Fun puzzle, although I had to brute force the crossing square of GNC and ACELAS.

All fair! I had no problem with the theme; it‚Äôs the sort of trick where one you know an EYE will be buried in the phrase, it‚Äôs easier to confidently fill with very few crosses (eg SMILEY EMOJI, DOUBLE YELLOW LINE).

My only real hiccup was the center of the grid, as I didn‚Äôt know MRE, DAG, AGEE, the meaning of ‚ÄúDiaphanous‚Äù, the character name ‚ÄúOlivia Benson‚Äù, or (with enough confidence) which vowel OYE ends in. Blindly throwing ‚ÄúGUARD‚Äù after the (obvious) ARM is what finally made it click into place, but I probably lost a good 30% of my solve staring at that spot.

Eye popping construction! I love how the EYE in each across entry is so cleverly hidden. It was fun tracking them all down, and the non-symmetrical placement upped the challenge a bit. 

ERLENMEYER FLASK and BREYER‚ÄôS ICE CREAM are my favorites. 

Fun misdirect listing all the dwarfs (except DOC, of course) for ADJS, and I also like.the clue for SHINER [‚ÄúYou might get one in a row‚Äù].

Congratulations, Adam and Chandi. You really scored a bullseye.
SOMETHING is singular.  DONKEY EARS is plural.  Aren't clues and answers are supposed to match?

Fun and challenging Sunday after a relatively easy Thursday - Saturday this week. Took me a while to figure out SNOD should've been SNOB and TIL Dreyers and Breyers are separate brands (and that Dreyers is the same brand as Edys, another crossword favourite)
That was great fun! My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/08/09/sunday-august-10-2025/#ny Thanks, Mr. Wagner and Ms Deitmer!

In the wee hours of Saturday morning, I commented about my disappointment in a few recent crossword answers that struck me as slurs against rural people. 

Thanks to everyone who read my comment and especially to those who replied. I read some of those replies during my pre-dawn insomnia, but I have been too busy today to respond. 

I hope to get a chance to reply to your comments later this evening or sometime tomorrow. If I do, I‚Äôll try to do so in a way that doesn‚Äôt require anyone to go back to yesterday‚Äôs comments. 

I truly value this forum as a place to carry on a dialogue about crosswords. I hope y‚Äôall do, too. 

Thanks.

I rolled my EYEs a bit when I worked out HONEYEATER, thinking it was some kind of... um, green paint (that's the term, right?) but I looked it up later because I have a tendency to assume I'm wrong and not the puzzle. Sure 'nuff! They are a cute family of birds I'd never heard of! I'm enthralled by the top two photos in this link, especially the second one: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-05-09/helmeted-honeyeater-endangered-bird-released-cardinia-shire/105003424 Anyhow, I've returned my EYEs to their locked and upright position and am happy to know about HONEYEATERS. Fun puzzle! A few areas of difficulty but I came in well under average. I figured there might be a rebus at SMILEYEMOJI but I hadn't figured out the revealer yet so I waited. At POPEYES, I was almost certain. Honestly, I should have been 100% there but I don't really roll that way confidence-wise. But then I got the revealer with only a few crosses and filled in those rebus squares with fair confidence. I shouldn't doubt myself so much, after all, I also wowed myself by remember ERLENMEYERFLASKS from college days with only a few crossings. And I spelled it right. Huzzah! Also, because why wouldn't you want more about my second home in Utila, Honduras? Our prima (cousin) was going to make us enchiladas, a favorite of mine, some years ago. Imagine my surprise when they turned out to be TOSTADAS, as we would call them here. They were excellent and she graciously makes them for us every year. So good!!
It‚Äôs CHEYENNE mountain.
That famous ErlenMeyerflask. It only takes one to ruin an entire puzzle
The thing I find frustrating about rebuses is that you can't make corrections to them in the online puzzles, or at least, I can't. So once you've made a stab, you're stuck with it.

TIL that a LAY is a ballad. Only got that one thanks to the crosses. 

And thanks to my kid who just took the chemistry placement test for college for ERLENMEYERFLASK -- that helped break open the rebuses. 

Overall a fun quick Sunday puzzle.
Thank you Adam and Chandi for a Sunday rebus! If you took a vote of solvers, the "ayes" would out number the nays.
Okay, so that Erlenmeyer Flask one? Really got me!  Who knew that was named after someone. Makes sense but that had me stumped!
The gimmicky stuff kills the Sunday puzzle for me.  Please please please keep it to Gimmicky Thursday?

I spied the need for a rebus when EYELET was too long for the allotted squares, and from there I was off and running‚Ä¶ until I got stuck. Too many crossing clues I simply didn‚Äôt know or couldn‚Äôt work out, especially in the upper half.

But despite needing a few lookups to proceed deliberately, I remain unprovoked. PHAT puzzle, fun theme. I liked it.

Marvelous puzzle.  40K feet above sea level right now. 

Spied on the family vacation, one pink croc that floated away when the wearer jumped away from a huge wave; elk in a reserve, seals sunbathing in a bay at both low tide and high tide, crabs crawling in lagoons, and cows basking with calves in sunlight. 

If you see a pink left croc size J4, just keep it and know that it was well loved.

My rule of thumb (nearly literally) is: 
one is one 
a couple is two 
a few is three 
some is four 
several is five to nine 
ten is ten 

so we're looking at a few ens in nonfiction, and to call it several would be a fiction. But maybe like grade inflation there is amount inflation. 

I sure was hoping for ARM ARMOR rather than ARM GUARD, but if I went out drinking in Boystown I might bring my ASGARD. Just kidding, y'all, jk!

Fun puzzle, especially liked 8A. Can't agree with the complaints about the number of names, most of them are pretty commonly known. I'm all for any puzzle doesn't need an Oreo or epee to fill in tight spots. They did, however, slip in ape as a verb, so there's that.

ERLENMEYERFLASK was a gimme for me, but I couldn't fit it in until I had the theme figured out. I had never heard of CHEYENNEMOUNTAIN, which was the last of the theme words I could fill in. But curiously enough, the one that made me decide that there definitely must be a rebus was POPEYES. Admittedly not as highbrow as EYEOFNEWT!

What really killed my NE was that I had confused buckeye for HAWKEYE. Got stuck until I read the column which had CHEW, leading to a real facepalm moment...

There's a complaint today about entering rebuses in puzzles. I'm sure this won't solve all rebus problems, but here's one thing that minimized my annoyance in this department: on my laptop, hitting the "esc" button allows me to type a rebus in a square.

And the theme song for this puzzle is brought to you by Hall and OATES. https://youtu.be/1A6gEuxMAAg?si=4NchLKxh6sj3w4ZQ (If you were a fan back in the day, I dare you to watch the original video and not cringe.)
I could never forget those Erlenmeyer flasks after my klutzy hands broke so many in organic chem lab that my physicist father almost cried at the bill üò≠.

Didn't realise I had to rebus EYE in each case, I just put "a little i" in each square ("CHINNEMOUNTAIN" & "OXIS" etc) - I think considering the description that should be acceptable! I spent about 10 minutes searching for errors after finishing before checking the comments and understanding the problem.
Fun puzzle though, good Sunday level with some nice clues - thanks!

EYE smelled the need for a rebus at HAWKEYE, but couldn‚Äôt immediately see the cross, as EYE was fixated on Pinocchio‚Äôs nose and didn‚Äôt remember the DONKEYEARS.  Once EYE got to EYELET, however, it was clear that the EYEs had it, and I could taste the solve coming my way. A pretty satisfying Sunday.

Three cheers for the AIMEE Mann reference.  She‚Äôs one of my favorite singer/songwriters, especially her Lost In Space disc. Once at one of her concerts, a fan requested a song to which she couldn‚Äôt remember the lyrics, so she borrowed the fan‚Äôs phone and sang the song.  Pretty nimble.

First pass, I knew Cheyenne Mountain (thanks, Stargate!) and Erlenmeyer flask, but second guessed myself when they didn't fit. Also second guessed SEMI because I really wanted "bah" for 102D (which I then put Meh for because I hadn't placed the EYE, and finally got MYEYE which I heard in Bones' voice. 

Why yes I am a geek :D

This was a good and fun puzzl(eye)s indeed!

Also I managed to fill without looking anything up. Not that I knew everything, but on the ones I didn't, crosses and a few educated guesses were enough. I like it when I can do that.
I was so disappointed - I was hoping that once solved, each rebus would turn into a little picture of an actual eye! (I apologize if someone already commented this.)

Loved this puzzle. It was clever and crunchy, and the theme was perfectly executed. It certainly had lots of proper nouns, many of which I was unfamiliar with, but with some analysis and educated guesses, I was able to 51A them all out with no lookups. Kudos to the creators!

For a while I got stuck in the NW, as nothing clicked right away, but I finally remembered ehow.com and that got me started. Picked up on the rebus fairly early with HAWK[EYE], and that got me OX[EYE]S and its crossing themer, and made it easier to recognize what was going on with the rest of the bunch.

It's been a long time (55+ years) since I had any need to handle ERLENMEYER FLASKs but the name popped up immediately; and even longer since I'd seen Pinocchio, so it took a couple crosses to remember those ears. Had a daughter that was into archery, so ARM GUARD was a gimme, and got me the U of SVU, which was a guess.

An English as a second (or later) language user on Reddit was asking about using 'spy' vs. 'see' just the other day, and respondents were being very nice for a change and explaining that 'spy' was not an everyday use term, and 'I Spy' was brought up several times, which made the revealer very easy for me.

Had a brief problem with candy vs. cookie, as I'd dropped in my old favorite Necco Wafers, rather than NILLA, but that got sorted with the crosses.

A fun one that turned out to be faster than I thought it would be after spending so much time being stuck, and it ended up getting done in 90 percent of my average time.

Thanks, Adam and Chandi!
I just love me a good ole Sunday rebus!
It took almost an hour and a half and I was surprised a bit by the music (figured something was wrong somewhere), but its done!

For the clue "Sort who won't need the advice 'don't look down' "I had "Eeyore," but spelled "Eyeore." The misspelling would have been obvious as soon as I looked at it except that the "eye" was entered as a rebus, was tiny, and  was rendered left-to-right instead of top-to-bottom, so it didn't register visually.
Went over everything and was wondering why I didn't get the music, and realized I had one extra EYE in the grid, in (EYE)SPYWITHMYLITTLEEYE - the one place my EYE should have been a (little) I!

96A turned out to be HON(EYE)ATER, but for a brief moment I thought about Hall and OATES (obviously since it was just a few answers before) and the song maNEATER came to mind‚Ä¶watch out ü§£ https://youtu.be/yRYFKcMa_Ek?si=cPL3ELSl-EjroUHK
We must've been on the same wavelength because this was a quicker than usual solve for me (slightly less than 45 min) with zero lookups. Very cute rebus and clever clues.
Loved it. Somehow donk(eye)ars was my first aha moment.

Well, I‚Äôve done it again: gotten in bed on Saturday night excited to do the Saturday crossword puzzle, finished it, only to find it I‚Äôve done the Sunday instead. I get foiled by this more often than I like to admit.

Somehow it took me forever to see what was right there before me: Ox eye daisies are a favorite, I myself am a Hawkeye, and the smiley emoji?  Maybe because it was a Sunday puzzle, I didn't expect rebuses, but when I finally saw what was happening, I was oohing and aahing over and over.  For this one, the ayes have it!  (Japanese yen was a stunner.)

Adam and Chandi, you constructed a magical puzzle, perfect for a Sunday, and I loved it.  Thank you.

Fun puzzle, interesting puzzle, streak-breaking puzzle (very, very modest streak breaker).

For whatever reason, I could not find DOUBL(EYE)ELLOWLINE.  I entered DOUBL(EYE)ELLOWLaNE, and never saw the other possibIlity.  And I know nothing of Radiohead, so I was hopeless there.  When I finally broke down and googled, I found KIDA.

And, even when I changed the A to an I, I didn't get the happy music.  That really startled me, and I resorted to Check Puzzle.

Turns out on one of my rebuses I had accidentally entered a single quote mark, 'EYE.  And that was the square that was wrong when I did check puzzle.

Can't win 'em all, he tells himself.

When I was in Chemistry I loved the Erlenmeyer Flask.  

It was so gorgeous.  Not as intimidating as the volumetric flask, with its weird single-marked neck atop a ridiculously big-bottomed bottom.  And those glass stoppers that you could never find when you needed them.  (I did love that the stopper was designed with a tab to be held between two fingers so you could take the top off and still have mostly two hands to work with.)

Much more aesthetic than the beaker, which, though useful, was where I was more likely to toss my trash solutions.  I never gave the beaker much respect.  Just a glorified kitchen glass.

The graduated cylinder was gorgeous, so tall and slender.  But they always felt to me like they were going to tip over and spill my solution and break the glassware all in the same once.

But the Erlenmeyer--what a flask!  The graduation marks didn't do volumes as well as the volumetric or the graduated cylinders, but they were certainly were more accurate than beakers.

And there was nothing in the world better made for swirling.  The quintessential chemistry cliche is a lab-coated scientist swirling an Erlenmeyer, looking at a beautiful colored solution through a pair of lab glasses.  Rarely happened.

I always felt confident with the Erlenmeyer: stable, handy, not too expensive, relatively easy to wash (unlike the awful volumetric flask).  Just the all-round great piece of lab equipment.

Sorry, got carried away.

What a fun puzzle. It was at Donk(eye)ars that I realized this was and (eye) rebus! I really like working rebus puzzles, so this one was especially fun. I loved the long themed ones. The only one that gave me a heck of a run was Doubl(eye)lowline.  I don't know why. After completing it, I couldn't figure out why it flummoxed me for so long. I had a typo that drove me bananas. When I finally found it, I saw that I had looked at it a dozen times. Super fun puzzle. Thank you Mr. Wagner and Deitmer. You guys rock. 

Y'all have a lovely Sunday. I'm gonna water my parched yard. We get 2 days to water now that we've had a little rain and our drought is a little better. It's gonna be very hot. Y'all stay cool, hydrated and safe. ‚úåÔ∏è

I found two clues immediately that led me to EYE BALL the correct rebus.

1) Besides being the location of NORAD, CHEYENNE MOUNTAIN is where I learned to ski. The ski area no longer exists but there is still a ZOO on the mountain. (And NORAD performs the important function of tracking Santa on Christmas eve.)

2)The only other name I accept for an Iowan is HAWKEYE, even though some of my elitist friends from both coasts refer to me as that 'hick' from Iowa. On the other hand, an Iowa State University Cyclone does not want to be referred to as a HAWKEYE, as the University of  Iowa  claims that nickname.

EYE enjoyed the puzzle and probably would have had a fairly fast time if I hadn't grabbed some SHUT EYE while solving.
My partner and I do the Sunday together and this was really fun. She's not a rebus fan but I think she enjoyed this one.
And another rebus, I‚Äôm done with you all. I‚Äôm canceling.

I enjoy the Sunday tricks & like a good rebus, but the entries related to the trick should be deducible. Erlenmeyerflask & Popeyes are both trivia you have to know and they cross on the trick.

Honeyeater I assume is some kind of hummingbird but is gettable from the crosses

Fun and imaginative crossword.  I have the NYT international edition and there were no ellipses on my puzzle ("each is clued with an entry in italics that starts with an ellipse") but just as well.  The Shakespeare clue at 86 down put me on the right track.

Crosswords

When everything feels frivolous,
decadent, absurd,
the oldest rebus in the book -
the eye -
crops up in a Sunday crossword
and you silently scream at your own
impuissance
but plod ahead and by the end
you are once again 
a creature with a soul, a heart,
a mind capable of anything.
The clue for 104A alone worth the price of admission. Thank you Adam and Chandi. 84A.

The spectre of US v UK spelling strikes again. I had an S instead of Z at 61D. Took me forever to find it. sOO didn‚Äôt hit my EYEBALL at all as being odd.

Great puzzle. I can confirm I have gone from team meh to team huzzah when I find a rebi puzzle.

I stuck with Etsy at 1A for too long, which held that corner up. I knew it had to be MOUNTAIN, but no clue as to its name. Couldn‚Äôt remember the flower name; I could only bring up Michealmas daisies which clearly didn‚Äôt fit.

Overall a lovely crunchy Sunday with a fun theme and some great fill. The Pinocchio clue made me chuckle once I worked it out.

Still trying to get some usable Alpaca fibre for knitting, but I think I‚Äôm losing. Despite many, many washes there‚Äôs just too much dirt embedded in there. I think it‚Äôs garden fleece only this year. Fingers crossed for an earlier shear date and no drought next year.

"Aha, a rebus puzzle!"

//wilts like an unwanted plant in a too-small pot

LAY Lady LAY takes on new meaning.

Had no idea.

DONKEYEARS for Pinochio and MRE for GI chow? Seriously???

Pinocchio grew his NOSE not his EARS. GIs eat a MESS. What is MRE?

How come the editors didn't catch these errors?

Also, the I SPY game never had that chant. We would just say I SPY something ___. And the game was then afoot.
LOVED it. Thank you, Chandi and Adam!
Fun Sunday puzzle. The rebus trick became clear for me with 26D ‚Äî POPEYES. It helps that I‚Äôve taught middle school science for 25 years, so I knew the answer to 39A ‚Äî ERLENMEYER FLASK.

I have now read through all 174 comments and have not seen a a comment by anyone who solves on paper, as I do, that in the .pdf version there are no italics to be seen. It didn't matter, since I discovered the rebus early with oxEYE. 

I know that when a puzzle treats solvers to a bit of animation at the completion, I can't expect the same for me. But it would be appreciated if the puzzle says "italics" in the clue, they should be there.

Liked this puzzle a lot, much more enjoyable than art heists and escape rooms.

Nice easy rebus puzzle, since each EYE was "hidden" only within its horizontal container.

Not quite a fastest-ever Sunday solve, but came in at less than half an hour.

Liked "Place with moving exhibits" for ZOO.

Hooray! And thank you, thank you, thank you. It's been too long since we had a rebus puzzle. Thank you, Adam and Chandi.

Doing the puzzle in pen on paper, I just sketched it, making it a traditional picture rebus. I've no idea how the online software handled it.

A fairly easy, Sunday-friendly rebus to get, I caught on right away with daisies and Iowans. Surprised myself to immediately remember the chem lab equipment.

It did seem like there were a lot of US-centric fill, I'm glad Andzrej has gone on holiday.
A pleasant solve.  Loved [Mega-store?] for HOARD.  Thanks for the explainers below on LAY.

The dreaded Sunday rebus puzzle!  

I caught on to the device with DOUBLEYELLOWLINE, but was flummoxed in the NE because I clung too long to ‚Äúblack eye‚Äù instead of the correct SHINER.  From my many years spent toiling in chem labs, I realized that ERLENMEYERFLASK was the correct fill.

A fun Sunday, although a few names slowed me down.

Terrific puzzle and I managed to solve it unaided. Very nice and chewy. I thought it was perfectly balanced with some easy fill to provide much-needed toeholds. 

Loved the title too‚Äî‚ÄúPassing Glances‚Äù so perfectly evoked the game of spotting items from a car speeding down the highway. Though it led me to try to picture seeing a tub of ice cream and a chem lab flask on the side of the road. On a billboard, maybe. I‚Äôm taking this too seriously. 

I haven‚Äôt finished in time to comment earlier this week but I did read the comments, and I have a thought on the topic of late-week puzzles getting easier. Someone commented yesterday or the day before that newer puzzles are less clunky and that has to do with better constructing tools, and I really think there might be something to that. When I do older puzzles it seems to me that there are more entries that are quite a stretch from the clue. I find myself saying, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how you want to describe that? Well okay, I guess.‚Äù I find that phenomenon much less in current puzzles.
Eye liked it.

This was fun today.

My favorite clue was probably 30D--very clever.

Got stalled by a couple of misspelled names--REiD and NEwMAN. No complaints, both totally fair words that I knew; I even paused as a filled in the errant W.

I had a rebus inkling before I was sure, but filling in the revealer helped. I particularly enjoyed the way the EYEs were split into non-ocular contexts.

Beat my Sunday average, but nowhere near a PB.

Thanks!

On the easy side, of course, but I always love a surprise twist on Sunday.

Did two Sunday puzzles this morning. Thought the completion times were interesting:

08/10/2025: 22:25
03/01/2020: 52:10

Looks like modern puzzles are less than half as difficult as they were at the start of COVID.

Finished a few seconds over my Sunday average, largely because I spent ten minutes searching for errors. Still, I enjoyed the puzzle, found several clues delightful mis-directs. Mega-store for HOARD. Place with moving exhibits for ZOO. You might get one in a row for SHINER.

One general comment about relatively difficult clues:

We often see complaints in these comments that such-and-such was too difficult‚Ä¶trivia that‚Äôs obscure, terms like MREs that are unfamiliar for us, rebuses. There‚Äôs a lot I don‚Äôt know and, lord help me but on the days I dare to look at the stats for solve times I pretty much always come away thinking, ‚ÄúGee, I thought I was getting good at this but clearly not.‚Äù Still, it‚Äôs a big wide world out there and people of a significant span of ages that do the NYT CW every day, so why does anyone think their knowledge and experience should be the benchmark for everyone else?

Fun theme, but it did feel like it took some forced clues to make it work.  I was initially going to come here and grouse (ha) about HONEYEATER, as I thought it was being used as an adjective, but I see from other comments that it is the proper name for a bird!  Good to know.

The clue that tipped me off to the theme was POPEYES.  I spent a few years in New Orleans, and retain quite an affection for the brand.  The service at each location was always punishingly slow, making you wonder why you continued to bother, and then you'd eat and remember why. üòÇ

I loved this puzzle - especially Erlenmeyer flask - a throw back to my Chem major days in college . Can someone explain how Ballad clues LAY ?? I got it from the crosses but I don't understand it at all .

I love a Sunday rebus puzzle; it feels like we're getting a bonus (or compensation, when Thursday is less than satisfying).
And hopefully this will be seen as an "entry-level" rebus that will convert a few rebus haters into reconsidering.
But still eight [EYE]s is impressive!  
(Google tells me that most spiders have eight EYEs.  Wouldn't it have been wonderful if this fact could have been part of the puzzle!)

And a great revealer.
I SUSSed out the revealer after I put in my first rebus, but I was thinking the whole time I SPY WITH MY LITTLE EYE has way too many letters to fit, but fit it did!

Big thanks to  Adam Wagner and Chandi Deitmer for this EYE-full construction.  Keep up the good work!
Such a fun puzzle..lots of twisty clues. I had a bit of trouble in the northwest..I didn't know the website or the mountain..but I made it!

Enjoyable Sunday.  Buckeye had me stuck in the NE for a long time.  Also had no clue about the donkey ears and thought for sure LAY was wrong but the crosses were all right and expected to have to go back and roll the middle letter if no gold star at the end.

This one is nitty but shouldn‚Äôt 32D have an indicator that Ump is an abbreviation?
14 D is wrong. It's the literary name, not the tv.
Imagine starting off your day with not one, not two, but EIGHT elegant and elegantly placed rebuses! Holy cow, this is gonna be a swell day -- thanks you guys!

Very enjoyable puzzle! It's a testament to my inexperience at this activity that I just swapped the "eye" for "i" in my fill and then spent 10 minutes looking for errors before realizing I had to rebus those squares. DONKIARS for me this morning.
Tough one for me.

OOooeee!  I see I am late to the party, here.  (DHubby slept in, or so I thought.  HE thought *I* was sleeping in... ) Oh, well.  He had pancakes on the table before I had this puzzle completed.  Printing on two pages is easier on the eyes, but a lot of back-and-forth with that approach, not to mention the cute misdirections and misreading of numerals.   I had the Reveal early on with the L and TT alone.  

Delightful.

The only one thing that felt slightly unfair was the DREYER'S.... which of course is regional.  DHubby buys ICE CREAM for himself....  To give him credit, he did bring home some Lactose-free Non-dairy concoction...also flavor-free and quick to crumble.  (I'm not making this up; it crumbles!)

For some reason, this puzzle seemed to flow nicely. I caught on to the rebussesses right away and proceeded with caution on many clues. They can be intimidating, but the zen of today's solve was apparent and I my wheelhouse.

I remember when everyone started playing "I Spy" nearly 20,000 years ago.

In case you didn't know, back then people had two differently-sized eyes, for important evolutionary reasons.

Our little eye could see objects far away, such as wolves, so we could spot danger. So one would say, "I spy with my "little eye" something that begins with a 'w' sound". (We didn't have alphabets yet, which is whatever, but also no alphabet soup, which was a bummer.)

Our big eye on the other hand(not literally) could see nearby objects. I still remember saying, "Look at the wolves surrounding us! They're so cute! Mommy, can we keep them and teach them tricks and let them sleep with us?!"

Anywho, I Spy was a very popular car game back then.

(It's a popular misconception that we didn't have cars that long ago. Of course we had cars. But we didn't have roads so we just sat in them and played I Spy or looked at our phones.)

I knew few of the proper nouns.  I think NEUMAN was my only gimme, as I was just at the right age for Mad Magazine's Golden Era.

I was so enchanted with Mad Magazine that when my mother and I first visited New York City, I forced her to walk in July heat to their offices on MADison Avenue.  I remember specifically pointing to the building with the address on its side, telling her it was only a "few" more blocks.

I assumed that such an august publication like Mad Magazine would have tours.  We went to the offices (the time before security) and walked in on the receptionist.  It was about lunch time, and everyone was away, but she was kind enough to show us all the rooms where the astonishingly creative artists and writers worked.

I was in awe when I saw an office with the name "William Gaines" on it. 

I always wondered if she told stories to the fabulous people who worked there about the crazy 16-year-old and his long-suffering Mother showing up to be entertained.

I really love New York.
